You set up social media profiles for the project on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Threads, YouTube, Mastadon, Reddit, Lemmy, K-Bin, Snapchat, WeChat, Academia.edu, ThinkHub… Remain in place.
Whoa! Your 10-second video sharing early results goes viral (among other academics). Move forward 2 spaces.
Whoa! Your 10-second video sharing early results goes viral on TikTok. You’re invited for a TV interview on CNBC. Move forward 6 spaces.
“The most important thing about this research is…” You spend a day in media training to learn how to talk about the project. Move forward 2 spaces.
You and your collaborators disagree about who should be listed as first author on the journal article introducing the project. Remain in place.
You and your collaborators change how the journal article introducing the project is structured, so that all the student workers can be listed as co-authors. Move forward 4 spaces.
Your proposal to a conference outside your field is rejected. Reviewers objected to the terms you used, instead of engaging with the project itself. Go back 1 space.
You’re almost done! You archive the project outputs and results and deliver them to your institution’s digital repository. Move forward 2 spaces.
After three years, your first student worker is about to graduate. You manage to hire them as part-time staff so they can keep working over the summer. Move forward 4 spaces.
“You can’t publicize this yet.” The Technology Licensing office needs to review your project in case the university wants to patent part of it. Skip a turn while you wait.
“This is amazing work! Can I use it in my classroom?” You present the project at a conference and find other scholars eager to engage. Move forward 6 spaces.
“Why would anyone want that?” You present the project at a conference and no one in the audience gets it. Go back 2 spaces.
You find other scholars (and internal funding) to organize a symposium contextualizing your project and building a community. Move forward 4 spaces.
All this success goes to your head. You stop mentioning your collaborators and research assistants in public talks. One of them calls you out on it. Go back 5 spaces.
You miss an email inviting you to a research symposium. Go back 1 space.
Your software developer’s laptop stops working. They hadn’t backed it up recently. You lose a good chunk of analyzed data. Go back 4 spaces.
You have stickers printed with the project name and logo. You pass them out at conferences. Move forward 2 spaces.
You introduce the project at a big campus symposium. An external scholar is invited to comment. They disagree with the premise of your project and say so. Go back 3 spaces.
You apply for another external grant. The first grant took four months to write. This one takes four weeks. You cross your fingers and move forward 2 spaces.
A postdoc in your department has an idea you really like. You can support them in spinning up a project and move forward 2 spaces. Or you can steal their idea and move forward 10 spaces.
Your project is selected for a prestigious international conference. Presenting your work to a global audience leads to valuable connections and collaborations. Move forward 6 spaces.
A collaboration opportunity arises with an industry partner. Their support enhances the practical applications and impact of your project. Move forward 5 spaces.
Your project is selected for a prestigious public humanities event, providing a platform to engage with a wider audience and share your research. Move forward 4 spaces.
One day, while visiting a different campus, you see one of your project's stickers on a random student’s laptop. You immediately email your team to tell them. Move forward 3 spaces.

Congratulations! Your project has been awarded a major, prestigious grant from a prominent foundation. The new grant gives you several years’ of runway and the ability to take the project in new directions. Move forward ten spaces.
A Ph.D. student at another institution forks your project code on GitHub. A couple of weeks later, they submit a pull request with several bug fixes. Move forward 3 spaces.

You and your colleagues rapidly write and submit three different journal articles to three different journals. Each article shows how your project speaks to major questions in each of your home disciplines. Move forward 4 spaces.
The interdisciplinary reading group that you joined when you just starting this project organizes a special symposium to celebrate your project’s launch. Move forward 4 spaces.
You get an email from a community member, telling you how much the project has benefited local schoolchildren. Move forward 6 spaces.
